Award.AwardTitle: CSR: Large: Storage Class Memory Architecture for Energy Efficient Data Centers

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
By 2011, data centers in the U.S. are poised to consume around 100 billion KW of energy, half of which in servers. The majority of power consumption will shift from the processor to main memory. This project, rather than relying solely on DRAM, uses multiple technologies to construct a high-capacity, energy-efficient memory system for virtualized computer servers with a new Storage Class Memory Architecture that incorporates multiple memory technologies such as DRAM, Phase-change memory (PRAM) and Flash.

This project is ambitious with fundamental and applied contributions in the design and development of energy-efficient computer servers. The fundamental contributions include: a new integrated memory architecture that seamlessly manages hybrid memory resources; novel algorithms and policies for energy, performance and endurance management; better understanding of the hypervisor?s role in resource management and its interaction with upper and lower system layers; and a new hybrid DRAM and PRAM main memory controller. The applied contribution is in the form of tools that will be developed and disseminate, including simulations, analytic models and actual software/emulated hardware system.

This research represents a new "green computing technology" that satisfies the demands of future computing systems (e.g., cloud computing, server farms, commodity computers) in an exceptionally low energy manner. The project impacts undergraduate and graduate students through research opportunities and industry internships and aims to recruit people from under-represented groups in computer science and computer engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Data centers in the United States are estimated to consume upwards of 100 billion KW of energy.  Around one half of this energy is consumed in the computer servers in the data center, with the bulk of an individual server's energy consumption coming from the memory.  This project developed a suite of techniques to reduce memory energy consumption for computer servers. A new memory system was designed that incorporated nonvolatile phase-change memory (PCM) that was combined with traditional volatile dynamic random access memory (DRAM).  By using nonvolatile, low energy memory with DRAM, the overall energy consumption of a computer server was reduced.   DRAM was used to mitigate challenges raised by PCM, including failure, long write latency and high write energy consumption. 

The intellectual merit of the project included fundamental contributions to memory architecture design to transparently manage multiple memory technologies and to integrate new memory technologies into computer servers; new algorithms and operating system policies to place and migrate data to the best memory resource for minimal energy consumption, while maximizing performance and prolonging the lifetime of the wear-prone PCM; new techniques in the memory hardware to mitigate harmful interference and competition for memory resources which can be amplified by the asymmetry of reads and writes for PCM; and new memory module and device designs to manage power consumption, extend memory lifetime and mitigate performance loss due to writes in PCM.

The project made societal broader impacts through the development of a new green computing technology.  This new memory technology was designed to lower the energy consumption of computer servers used in cloud computing, server farms and even commodity systems. Numerous scholarly articles were published to broadly disseminate the outcomes of the work.  The project also had several applied contributions through the development of software tools, including a simulator for computer memory design.   The project trained undergraduate and graduate students in research on memory systems.
